body: @leventov Hi, Leventov. I executed the `git rebase --root --onto master --preserve-merges` command on `code_refactoring` branch and get the `Successfully rebased and updated refs/heads/code_refactoring.` message. Is that ok?
If that is fine.  I would push it with the `git push -u origin code_refactoring --force` command.

@leventov Already Done.

```bash
git rebase --abort
git checkout code_refactoring
git checkout -b re2
git branch root bbb61e638b391d29
git checkout re2
git diff master > ../123.patch
git checkout master
git checkout -b r2
git apply ../123.patch
git diff master
git status
git diff --name-status | wc -l
git add .
git status
git diff master
git commit -m 'Improve `collection` related things that reusing a immutable object instead of creating a new object'
git status
git push origin r2:code_refactoring -f
```

Why i changed nothing, but i got the `The job exceeded the maximum time limit for jobs, and has been terminated.` message from `travis`? It seems like the time length limitation of the time of build job is 50min in travis.org. (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build#Build-Timeouts)

Can anyone help me to restart the build job?
I vote for 2.

Thanks for the report @cesure. It looks like this is due to NamespaceLookupExtractorFactory accepting CacheScheduler when instantiated, which is not a singleton and so it's created each time a "cachedNamespace" is deserialized.

@leventov this changed in #3697, where NamespaceLookupExtractorFactory used to take a (singleton) NamespaceExtractionCacheManager but now takes a (not singleton) CacheScheduler. Would it make sense to make CacheScheduler a singleton or is some other approach warranted?
I think it'd be fine to pull it back to 0.10.1 if you want, undocumented APIs are undocumented so we don't have to worry about compatibility. Up to you though.
@asdf2014 looks like the tests have passed now. thanks for the contribution!
@pjain1 #4279

@asdf2014 irrelevant now but actually what you did is rebase of your entire branch, that is also should be avoided. I asked to rebase only the _latest commit_ in the branch, which you was proposing to merge into druid-io/druid/master, `asdf2014:code_refactoring`. That commit used to be called "Fix conflicts".
The interface changed, but I think there's no compatibility issue since HavingSpec isn't one of the listed extension points.
can you please do it in a branch, that would be easier to test ?
Will likely be part of #4178.
Fixed by #4115

Brought up on the dev sync and @himanshug pointed out some people prefer these due to speed. Maybe instead of deprecating the old endpoints we could document that they don't include the freshest information?

Or we could do best of both worlds, maybe, and cache segment metadata query based stuff on the brokers.
@xvrl are you still interested in this one?
@gianm I believe @cheddar was the one who had requested this as a follow-up but we never got around to it. If someone else wants to take it over, feel free.

@b-slim that sounds good, let's stick with Hadoop 2.7. Have you had a chance to test this on an external Hadoop cluster? I think the last thing we need to do is push the Druid properties into the map/reduce JVMs, otherwise the loadSpec will always show 'local'

do you know if you'll have time to look at this for 0.10.1?

@jihoonson `Execs.newBlockingSingleThreaded("publish-%d", 0)` will create an executor with `SynchronousQueue` which is blocking and not unbounded. Am I missing anything ? Ultimately `publishExecutor` should be a single threaded non blocking executor working off of an unbounded queue. Does this make sense ?
Oops, hit close by accident.
@pjain1 https://github.com/druid-io/druid/tree/queryMetrics-concurrency-fix
@leventov thanks
https://github.com/metamx/druid/tree/cacheScheduler-singleton might fix this
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-394 is not fixed yet although there is a patch out.

@gianm Ignoring the current configs in this PR, moving forward something like this can be done-
1. If `tlsPort` is set and is different from `port` then two connectors will be opened one for http and other for https.
2. If `tlsPort` is set and is same as `port` or `port` is not set then use `tlsPort` to open https connector.
3. Otherwise use `port` to open http connector.
4. Fail in any other situation
In this world if users want https then they must set `tlsPort`.

Another design would be to have a config like `druid.server.https.enabled` -
1. Have same default value of `tlsPort` and ` port`
2. If the config is set and `tlsPort` and ` port` value is equal then open an https connector.
3. If the config is set and both ports values are different then open both http and https connector.
4. If the config is not set then use `port` value to open an http connector.
In this world, if users just want https then they must either set `port` to -1 or set equal value for `port` and `tlsPort`

There can be multiple combinations with these 3 configs. What do you think is better ?
@gianm I did a quick check with some people who were using these endpoints. They now use similar endpoints provided by coordinator. so those at broker can be removed now.
Would be good to email out to druid-development as well, I think, to make sure nobody misses the PR.

@gianm yeah i had sent a mail in druid-dev as well, updated the description with that thread.
let us not merge it just yet and let it sit for a little while.
There's a /leader endpoint that will return the addr of the leader as well

One more option is to have a config like `druid.server.http.disable` (defaults to `false`) and `druid.server.https.enable` (defaults to `false`) . These two properties directly correlate to `port` and `tlsPort` on `DruidNode`. HTTP connector always uses `port` and HTTPS always uses `tlsPort`. If we want standard TLS ports then they can be the default port number + 100 or something like that.

Both of those seem a bit magical to me. If I'm a user I don't want to have to worry about whether `port` and `tlsPort` are the same and what implications that has.

Instead how about the following?

- set default tlsPort for each service to existing plaintext ports + 200; so broker is at 8282, historical is at 8283, MM tlsStartPort is at 8300, etc.
- have a config `druid.server.http.tls` which defaults to false, but if enabled, turns _on_ the tls ports.
- have a config `druid.server.http.plaintext` which defaults to true, but if disabled, turns _off_ the plaintext ports.
- users can customize port/tlsPort/startPort/tlsStartPort if they want, but we expect that most users won't.
- maybe deprecate the "port" configs and rename them to something like druid.plaintextPort?
oops, should have said `druid.server.http.plaintext` would default to true. Edited the last comment.
That's true, although it's not useful for the case I mentioned.
Interesting, my last comment looks similar to what you are proposing.

Yes it does look similar :)

I like `druid.server.http.tls` and `druid.server.http.plaintext` -- to me it's easier to scan and understand something like `http.plaintext=true` than `http.disable=false` (the double negative is weird).
OK lets go with the properties name you suggested. I'll make the changes soon. Thanks for the comments.

our setup still uses autoscalers to roll out new versions, so we require having the supported upgrade path be upgrading the overlord first and allowing the middle managers to dynamically scale as they naturally age off.
With this change then it will be ok to do things which break "overlord first" upgrades
If port is deprecated and if user was setting port using config then do we expect user to change it to plaintextPort or should the code internally map port to plaintextPort.

@pjain1 @gianm 

Having two types of ports and a separate configuration to enable each type sounds good to me.

I think we could keep `port` as-is without deprecating (I feel like it should be sufficient to make that distinction in the docs without needing users to make configuration changes for all plaintext ports), but if we do, I'd favor treating `port` and `plaintextPort` as equivalent. 

If both plaintext/TLS ports are enabled, I think having `port` and `tlsPort` be the same should be an error condition instead of having TLS silently take precedence, I feel like behavior is more clear then.

@fjy restoring 0.10.1 milestone because it's an important change that restores compatibility of segment metadata queries.

@gianm @drcrallen could you please review the design again?

> If port is deprecated and if user was setting port using config then do we expect user to change it to plaintextPort or should the code internally map port to plaintextPort.

In this case I'd expect the code to map port internally to plaintextPort. The idea would be that if a user isn't using tls, they shouldn't have to change anything in their config.

We don't necessarily need to deprecate port at all though, `druid.port` could basically mean "plaintext port". I'm not sure what's best, could go either way.

> If both plaintext/TLS ports are enabled, I think having port and tlsPort be the same should be an error condition instead of having TLS silently take precedence.

That does sound like it should be an error.
@pjain1 ah right. It should be some reasonable large value _k_ >> 0 which doesn't exceed VM limit. I think it should be configurable. Does it make sense?

By _k_ you mean the queue capacity ? If _k_ is set to a large number then why not just use `Execs.singleThreaded` where the queue is unbounded, is there any problem ? Unless it should be bounded to a some small number in case of `IndexTask` then it makes sense for it to be configurable. 

I guess I am OK with both approach, having it configurable or using `Execs.singleThreaded`. Its your call.

Ah right. I didn't notice the ```Execs.singleThreaded()``` method. It makes more sense. 
Does it make sense to use ```ListenableFuture``` to you? If so, I'll raise a new PR for the refactoring of ```AppenderatorDriver```. After that, I think we can proceed this PR and #4238 individually.

> The data model used by other systems would generally be more sophisticated than the basic RBAC model proposed here (for example, the Athenz system linked by @pjain1 has more concepts like domain namespaces and services).
> 
> I don't think we could capture every data model variation if the extension point is at the User/Role/Permission level, and it would be cleaner/more useful to not impose such assumptions on an extension implementer.

I think I agree with this -- that way we aren't forcing people to use an identical RBAC model to our "standard" model for authorization.

Although, this is apparently the road Hive went down. @nishantmonu51, do you have a sense about how successful that has been? Do implementations usually implement all the HiveAuthorizer methods and do you know if there have been issues mapping that onto systems whose authorization models aren't the same as Hive's?
I think it is ok for it to return ListenableFuture. Thanks
Thanks. I think it will take about 2 days. I'll ping you when I raise the PR.
@leventov Sorry violate druid code style... I got it, in fact i also liked squash those commits into a single commit. @gianm You are welcome.

@asdf2014 for the future PRs - please _**don't squash anything**_ after you submitted a PR and some time has passed so somebody may has already started looking at your PR (and, moreover, if somebody already left some review comments), because reviewers lose the progress and in some cases need to re-review the whole PR, to be sure that they didn't miss anything.
Okay, you are right. Those messages of commits should be retained.

In addition to the messages, Github also has a nice feature that lets reviewers see what has changed since their last review. It's based on diffing against new commits though, so squashing prevents that feature from working.

FWIW we only very recently changed our guidelines to suggest that people avoid squashing (#4087). Until then we did suggest squashing, but we changed our minds :)
Oh... Don't know these, i will pay attention in the future.
No worries, and thanks again for the patch.
Alright, you are welcome.
@b-slim done.
ok

Thank you @leventov!

I just backported this single commit locally into 0.10.0 will try it on our dev cluster.

@drcrallen right, this authorizes code changes that require "middle manager" first upgrade and not "overlord first".
with this, autoscaling will still work but with changed step of first increasing worker version on overlord, let it create new updated MMs and then update overlord to new version.

sounds like we are talking about 4 properties ...
```
druid.port or druid.plainTextPort
druid.tlsPort
druid.server.http.plaintext=true/false
druid.server.http.tls=true/false
```

how about having just 2 properties instead..
```
druid.port or druid.plainTextPort
druid.tlsPort
```

and have the behavior be following.
1. If nothing is specified, behavior stays same as now, only http connector is started on current default ports.
2. if either or both are specified then appropriate http connectors (http or https or both) are started.

@drcrallen there are tests with mocks which did not cover this specific change. i tried that today but looks like it would need some refactoring in there to make it testable where in the response handler could be exercised. 
anyways, I have now tested it on our integration testing environment and its working.
@leventov its passing our integration testing env. please do the pr.
@himanshug are you trying to add unit test or is this mergeable ?
Does this solve https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/1415 ?

@drcrallen this (and #4229 ) solve #1415 partially , timeout handling probably needs to be handled in many different places to fully solve #1415 . this should solve it at broker for queries which are processed fully in streams.

@pjain1 no, not in this pr at least. this is mergeable.
@leventov I tried this and integration tests seems to be passing

I think in the vast majority of cases we're really talking about just two properties, since most users will keep `druid.port` and `druid.tlsPort` at the default values and therefore not have to specify them in config.

One thing that seems weird to me about the "2 property" approach is that `druid.port` and `druid.tlsPort` have default values, and leaving the props out (i.e. keeping default values like 8282 for the broker) and explicitly specifying the same value (i.e. `druid.tlsPort=8282`) would have different behavior.
I personally like 4 properties approach, keeps thing clear.
@himanshug @pjain1 please check #4288
@himanshug perhaps you could add some rationale as well -- what would be helpful about making this change?
+1, aws-java-sdk seems better than jets3t these days. Related: #4116 which would add support for s3a (aws-java-sdk backed S3) to Hadoop indexing.
There are some in the community who use jets3t.properties, so such a change would either need a migration plan or a major version update

My feeling is it's not worth supporting both at the same time, and instead we should do it in 0.11.0 and tell people that jets3t properties will no longer be respected (but whatever new aws-java-sdk configurator thing will).

@gianm with "2 properties" approach
- "default" case is when user does not say anything about ports in properties . and then http connector is started on current default port. note that no https connector is started in this case.
- if user specifies any port then there is no "default", system does exactly what is said in the config.  That is
  (1) if user only specified `druid.port` then only http connector is started.
  (2) if user only specified `druid.tlsPort` then only https connector is started.
  (3) if user specified both then both http and https connectors are started.

So, there are no default tls ports.

That said, "4 properties" might be a more commonly understood model as terradata has that too ( https://teradata.github.io/presto/docs/current/security/internal-communication.html ) and at least 2 people in this PR appear to like that more :) .
Thanks for the report @elloooooo. I marked this 0.10.1 to remind us to check it out before the release.
@gianm agreed. also it wasn't clear in my prior message, but I think moving to the AWS sdk is a great idea.

@gianm rationale is described in PR description. we want to bring coordinator and overlord upgrade next to each other so that they can be updated together as would be necessary when user runs them in one single process.

@drcrallen is that clear what is motivating the update order change or I need to add more color to the description ?
Duplicate of #3886
@leventov can't we make QueryPlus threadsafe in general and not worry about what type of QueryRunner uses it?

I think a lot of this is because real Kafka brokers are getting setup and torn down with each test. I like that they're real instead of mocks (helps this be like a mini-integration-test) but we could reuse them. Maybe a different topic for each test, that way we don't need to tear down and recreate the whole broker.
I understand why the change is desired. I just disagree that the upgrade order that has been supported for a very long time should be abandoned for an optional setting.

@himanshug it's not about `QueryPlus` per se, it's about `QueryMetrics`. Making `QueryMetrics` thread-safe is harmful, because instead of solving the problem it hides the problem. If for some query types `QueryMetrics` need to accumulate information from multiple threads (where parts of the query are processed/executed), this information should be passed up via Futures which already exist, and aggregated in a single thread. So far there is no such need.
@jihoonson please resolve conflicts. Going to merge this PR tomorrow unless somebody else wants to review.

@gianm QTL mandated that coordinator gets updated in the end after all the lookup nodes ( i.e. historicals, brokers, middle-managers)  so we couldn't move it up next to overlord.

in general, then we can have two sets of rolling upgrade orderings and formally support both.
@fjy FYI you can restart a build without closing/reopening PR: http://stackoverflow.com/a/17624403/648955
@leventov yes i Know but it is easier to close/reopen
You should probably be on the travis page anyway though, to check if the failure was a legitimate issue with the patch or not.
@leventov thanks. Resolved conflicts.
@jon-wei thanks. I addressed your comments.

I have some problem about timezone. I am in China and I want to set my timezone to Standard Time in China.  I tried many, such as "Asian/Beijing", "Asian/Shanghai" and "Asian/Chongqing". But none of them work as expected. Who can tell me what's wrong and list the valid timezone values?
Any ideas would be appreciated!
@PanYifeng, there is a list on wikipedia here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones. An offset should also work, like "+08:00" or "-03:00".
Regarding having modular RBAC system, an example of that would be Apache Ranger.
@gianm Thank you! On referring to List_of_tz_database_time_zones, I found I had made a spelling mistake. As I replaced "Asian/Shanghai" with "Asia/Shanghai", the problem was solved.

Making CacheScheduler a singleton fixed the problem for us!

I can't comment on any side effects this change eventually brings in for now, though.
